Award.AwardTitle: Study of the Reaction between Nitrogen Monoxide and Carbon Monoxide in the Presence of Double Metal Cyanides for the Potential Application as Emission Control Catalyst
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemical Catalysis Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, Professor Jianfeng Jiang of Yeshiva University will study the reaction of nitrogen monoxide and carbon monoxide in the presence of double metal cyanides (DMC) for the potential application as emission control catalysts. The proposed study will start with the exploration of the synthesis of first row transition metal mixed cyanide/carbon monoxide complexes that are also of fundamental interest. Afterwards, studies of the reactivity of the carbon monoxide-coordinating metal cyanides or DMCs with nitrogen monoxide/dinitrogen monoxide will follow. The studies will also include analysis of nitrogen monoxide/dinitrogen monoxide with carbon monoxide in the presence of DMCs.

This research is relevant because of the possibility of preparing new carbon monoxide-coordinating metal cyanides, new types of DMCs and high temperature stable carbon monoxide-coordinating polymers, and the potential for developing alternative emission control catalysts. For example, if the reduction of nitrogen monoxide/dinitrogen monoxide to dinitrogen by carbon monoxide is greatly accelerated by a DMC, this DMC can be used to replace precious rhodium, platinum and palladium metal inside catalytic converters. In addition, undergraduate students who participate in the research will benefit by having first-hand research experience, working on solving problems directly related to our environment, manuscript writing and communicating results in formal presentations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the NSF-supported research period of reaction of NO/N2O with CO-coordinating Double Metal Cyanides (DMC), we have produced significant results which will benefit our society scientifically and on an educational scope.

On a scientific perspective, we discovered new but very basic reaction systems related to nickel and cobalt carbonyls. We have proved that nickel cyanides can be reduced by carbon monoxide in basic solution even at room temperature and regular pressure. This discovery has enabled us to build a CO-powered fuel cell and demonstrated the convenient and efficient energy conversion from chemical energy inside CO to electricity without combustion. This result has been published in a well-respected journal and highlighted in the front cover page. This discovery is a valuable addition to collective effort in the next generation fuel cell study in the United States. It may lead to the clean conversion of chemical energy stored in coal to electricity with the right infrastructure support.

We have made and identified the structures of a series new CO-containing DMCs. Among them, Prussian Red (a name we assign to the CO-containing mixed valence iron cyanides) shows very rare 3:2 octahedron : square topology in space. Prussian Red also shrinks upon heating. This rare thermal property may lead to the applications in multi-functional specialized materials.

DMCs based on NO-containing cobalt cyanide were also discovered. These DMCs may be able to catalyze the decomposition of NO to the non-toxic nitrogen and oxygen gas.

We have spent a lot of effect studying the reactions between CO and NO in the presence of the synthesized DMCs.  Since both CO and NO are the major pollutants from internal combustion engine, if our DMCs can catalyze their reaction to produce non-toxic carbon dioxide and nitrogen gas, these DMCs potentially can replace expensive noble metals currently used in emission control catalysts. 

The study of CO and NO reaction in the presence of out DMCs has not completed. Our initial study has found that CO and NO reacted at around 250oC to produce nitrogen gas, carbon dioxide and maybe nitrous oxide (laughing gas). The conversion precentage, however, is relatively low (less than 50%). We are still working on finding the best DMC and refining the best working condition.

Educationally, the research conducted with undergraduate students from both men’s and woman’s colleges of Yeshiva University demonstrated the feasibility of conducting experimental research in an orthodox Jewish envionment.  Undergraduate students who participated in the research were benefited by having first-hand research experience, manuscript writing and communicating results in formal presentations.  Support from NSF provided more research experience to undergraduate students and better prepare them for research career in experimental science.  

With the support of NSF through this award, four undergraduate students have traveled to American Chemical Society meetings to present their work to a much broader audience. six students are co-authors to the papers we have published. More students will be co-authors for the subsequent publications.  

During the study, four undergraduate students and the PI have worked together to design a crystallization in agar gel laboratory experiment for college students. This laboratory experiment will help students better understanding crystal lattice, crystalization and diffusion processes. 

The development of CO-powered fuel cell also has attracted interests from the general public.  Some inventors have showed interests in the idea of CO-powered fuel cells.  In addition, lectures to the general public and the work on catalytic CO oxidation has raised energy awareness within Yeshiva University.

Modified by: Jianfeng Jiang
